final_answer.precision_note: 3 significant figures, matching the precision of the NaOH volume (23.40 cm3 has 4 s.f., limited by 0.150 with 3 s.f.)

method: First calculate moles of NaOH: n = c × V = 0.150 mol dm-3 × (23.40/1000) dm3 = 0.00351 mol. From the equation H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O, the mole ratio is 1:2, so moles of H2SO4 = 0.00351 / 2 = 0.001755 mol. Calculate concentration of H2SO4: c = n/V = 0.001755 mol / (25.00/1000) dm3 = 0.001755 / 0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3. The 1:2 stoichiometry means the acid concentration is half what it would be for a 1:1 reaction.
checks: Stoichiometry check: dibasic acid requires half the moles of NaOH - verified (0.00351/2 = 0.001755)
Magnitude check: acid volume similar to base volume but half the moles needed, so concentration should be about half - verified (0.0702 vs 0.150)
Unit consistency: cm3 converted to dm3 consistently - verified
